metadata.case_name: Shree Sitaram Sugar Co. Ltd., Baitalpur v. Workmen and State of U.P.

facts.text: The appellant, a public limited company carrying on business of manufacture and sale of sugar from sugarcane, employs about a thousand workmen in its factory at Baitalpur.
The appellant retired three workmen, namely, Chhatradhari Lal, Chandrika Prasad Srivastava and Bal Karan. This led to an industrial dispute.

The State Government by Notification No. 785/LC XVIII LA-97 GR /1959 dated October 25, 1960, referred the said dispute to the Labour Court, Gorakhpur, for adjudication (Reference No. 1, registered as Adjudication Case No. 93 of 1960).
The Labour Court passed an award dated February 26, 1961, holding that the retirement of the three workmen was neither legal nor justified.
The award in Reference No. 1 was published in the U.P. Gazette dated May 6, 1961, by the State Government's Notification dated April 4, 1961, No. 1176 EIO 36/ A/46 ST -59.

Similar disputes regarding the retirement of several other workmen (about thirty or forty, including the three in Reference No. 1) referred by State Government Notification No. 322 LC XVIII-LA-115, GS /1959 dated October 31, 1960 (Reference No. II, Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960).

The three workmen covered by Reference No. 1 made an application to the Labour Court for deleting their names from Reference No. II on the ground that their grievance is the subject of adjudication in Case No. 93 of 1960. The Labour Court by order dated February 21, 1961, accepted the prayer.

Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960 resulted in an award dated February 27, 1961, deciding the dispute on merits but specifically stating no finding with regard to the three workmen covered by Reference No. 1 as their names were excluded.
The award in Reference No. II was published in the State Gazette on April 4, 1961.

After the award on February 26, 1961, the State Government issued Notification dated February 28, 1961, withdrawing the Notification dated October 25, 1960, making Reference No. 1, under sub-section (1) of section 6-G of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

The appellant filed Writ Petition in Allahabad High Court under Article 226 for certiorari quashing the award dated February 26, 1961, and mandamus directing State Government to withdraw publication on May 6, 1961.
Learned single Judge held withdrawal order of no effect as power cannot be exercised after award made; dismissed writ.
Special Appeal No. 960 of 1964 dismissed by Division Bench on August 2, 1966, holding power under s.6G exists but no pending proceedings after award.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the State Government has power under section 6G of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 to withdraw an order already passed referring a dispute for adjudication.
If yes, whether the power under section 6-G can be exercised after an award has been made by the Labour Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 6-G confers an absolute right on the State Government to withdraw an order already passed referring a dispute for adjudication, distinct from power to transfer; can be exercised till the award becomes enforceable under s.6-D.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 6-G, U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; Section 6-D

respondent_arguments.text: Section 6-G confers only power to transfer proceedings from one Labour Court/Tribunal to another; no power to withdraw simpliciter. Even if power exists, cannot be exercised after award made as proceedings conclude.

court_reasoning.text: Section 6-G deals only with power to transfer proceedings; withdrawal is incidental for purpose of transfer. 'Or' in s.6-G(1) to be read as 'and' having regard to scheme of the Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Superficial reading suggests two powers, but context limits to transfer power.

court_reasoning.text: Once award made, proceedings not pending for withdrawal. Sections 6 and 6A make publication mandatory and award final.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No absolute withdrawal power to nullify proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Section 6-D irrelevant for construing s.6-G; for determining pendency in other contexts like ss.6E, 6F.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.6-D creates fiction for specific purposes.

court_reasoning.text: No conflict between awards; three workmen excluded from Ref II.

holdings.text: State Government has no power under s.6G to withdraw a reference order simpliciter; only to withdraw for transfer to another Court/Tribunal.
Withdrawal notification dated Feb 28, 1961 invalid; award and publication valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mazagaon Dock Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax and Excess Profits Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Or' can be read as 'and' in certain circumstances having regard to scheme.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Sirsilk Ltd., and Others v. Government of Andhra Pradesh Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Concerned mandatory publication under ss.17,18 Central Act; not applicable here.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to refer disputes (4K), procedure for awards and publication (6), commencement/conclusion of proceedings (6D), power to transfer/withdraw (6G); award final on publication.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The Supreme Court holds that the State Government lacks power under section 6G to withdraw the reference simpliciter after an award is made. The withdrawal notification is invalid, the award dated February 26, 1961, and its publication are valid and binding.

key_quotes.text: The short question that arises for consideration in this appeal, by special leave, is whether the State Government has power under section 6G of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 hereinafter to be referred to as the Act to withdraw an order already passed referring a dispute for adjudication.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 6-G, in our opinion, deals only with the power of the State Government to transfer a proceeding from one Labour Court or Tribunal to another and for purposes of such transfer to withdraw the proceedings from the Labour Court or Tribunal from whom it is being transferred.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key interpretation limiting s.6G to transfer power.

key_quotes.text: The proper way of reading section 6-G is to limit the power of withdrawal, referred to therein, only for the purpose of transferring the proceedings from one Labour Court or Tribunal to another. That the expression 'or' in section 6-G (1) interposed between 'withdraw any proceedings' ..... 'or transfer a proceeding' will have to be understood as 'and'.
key_quotes.speaker: court
